It recreates my very lungs to think
How this luxurious stupid Heildebrand
In pleasure snorts, and little thinks
He shall be waked with an alarm.
You, Sir, must take important care, lest in
The streets your consultation be with throngs
Of Fiends: for busy members will be soon
Observed; your quarter is the Western bridge.
But first attend about the Palace, to
Expect your orders, they must be given you there.
Direct yourselves; I am more watchful than
A sick Constable after his first sleep
On a cold bench, Hirco, along with me.
This is the Count Rangone, Sir, who was
Before your Conquest here chief Captain of
The Guard unto the captive Prince.
From Galeotto, Sir, is your affair?
This Ring he humbly sends a present to
Your Majesty, it was the first rich pledge
You gave him to confirm his new integrity,
By which he would persuade your royal thoughts;
In a messenger of trust, with hope
It may procure me privately your ear.
Leave us, Morello, and attend within
What is the cause he can so soon neglect
The homage of his duty here? he did
Not wait today.
His daughter, Sir, is sick.
over whom so fondly he laments, that he
Supplies both her Physicians Art and diligence.
Proceed to his request.
Your wisdom, Sir, we will much admire.
To what a calm and easy sufferance
He hath reduced Arthiopa reclaimed
Her frosty nature to such warm, such soft
And feminine desires as it is fit
Her beauty should possess.
Thou dost bewitcheth me with thy news.
Sir, she no more retains the seeming forwardness
And peevish rigour of a maid,
But wonders why the Roman Lucrece did
Complain, because enforced since boldly she
Concludes it now the only subtle way
To compass pleasure without sin.
Wise Aracmes Philosophy, he would read
It to his Niece.
No question, Galeotto had
Good modern Authors for his Doctrine, Sir,
Else it would not thrive so well: his instant suite
Unto your greatness is, you would prepare
To humble your occasions to this night,
As you may visit him; and you shall find
The Lady altered to your wish.
It lay not in the power of all his skill
And vigilance, to send me a request
I would so willingly receive: this glad
Assurance render him with my best thanks,
And then return to be my guide.
Stay here, and watch for more supplies: the word
Is gone about, I have drawn to our confederacy
From an obscure blind lane, a race of such
Indebted wights, as have not seen the Sun
Since the last great eclipse, when wonder more
Than business brought them out.
Have they any clothes?
Why, dost thou think they go to play a Prize?
Is it of necessity they must appear
In scarlet Breeches, and clean laced shirts?
Swords they have all, although their scabbards are
A little torn about the Chape, they will serve
To poke; less men are squeamish, and will not let them
Enter their bodies, because they are rusty.
I would not be a Sergeant in their way.
Straight when the hurry shall begin to rise,
Beware my Gossip Goldsmiths shop; there be
Among us that will drink our mornings draughts
In plate, without asking how much an ounce.
Look there, you must wear an invisible Ring.
He said I should receive the Lady here;
It is strange he fails: if Sir, it will become
Your greatness to expect a while, I will seek
Galeotto out, and sent her hither.
The object may deserve my patience, but take care
You are swift in your return.
If wishes can
Conduce prosperity to the design,
Thou shalt not want them, Altophil, I will guard
The gates below to hinder all impediments.

stage.l: Exit, strange music is heard above.

sp.l: This sure is some preparative, although
The sound is not very amorous.

stage.l: The Song to a horrid tune.

sp.l: You Fiends and Furies come along,
With Iron Crow and massy Prong;
Come, drag your shackles and draw near,
To stir a huge cold Sea-coal Cake,
That in our hollow hell did bake,
Many a thousand thousand year.
In Sulphurous broth Tereus hath boiled,
Basted with Brimstone, Tarquin hath broiled
Long, long enough, then make more room
Like smokey flitches hang them by
Upon our sooty walls to dry,
A greater ravisher will come.
If you want fire, fetch a supply,
From Aetna and Puteoli,
Yet stay a while, you need not stir,
Since if his glowing eyes shall chance,
To cast on Proserpine a glance,
He is so hot he will ravish her.
My sense are grown sick! speak! what art thou?
Men call me Altophil.
He I encountered in a battle on
The banks of Sibaris? I will rather meet
Thee in that river, stemming against
The tide, than thus walled in where horror dwells.
I am betrayed! --
Stir not, you are confined,
And cannot scape me now; for such events
As are prescribed us in the secret book
Above, here we shall both receive.
I fear not mine, my single valour is
Enough, if thou art all mine enemies.
You come to visit Galeotto, Sir:
See where he rudely sits ill-mannered Lord,
That will not rise to welcome such a Potentate.
Sleeping in death! such nodding likes me not.
Survey him well, he was your Traitor, Sir.
Go hug him now; cherish the falsehood that
Could ruin States, and draw a Nation to
Captivity; open his head, where all
His plots and policies are treasured up,
And take them out, it is not fit such wealth
Should lie concealed in the grave.
Is there no more
Remaining of those sweating toils, danger,
And studious wit that helps ambition to
Ascend, than such a pale complexion and
a cold dumb mockery of what we were?
Now, Sir, to entertain your precious time
With new variety (although I knew
You are in haste) see Amaranta here.
She so altered and grown silent too?
This was a noble beauty once; replete
With all that gentle ornament Lovers
In their kind passion, or Poets in
Diviner fury could advance with praise.
And this so sanctified a thing, you did
Endeavour to corrupt, pray court her now,
And third her tears like oriental Pearl,
Take Rubies from her lips to darken all
The Jewels in your Crown, you have undertook
So much in counterfeit Hyperbole's,
Blast her fair hand with your false sighs; and swear
It is no Idolatry, you may; for look
How like a Goddess a dead Lady shows.
I will see no more; if they are fit for monuments,
Why were they not interred before I came?
Yes, you durst needs behold all that is gay
And pleasing here; it will make your welcome seem
More absolute: come forth Arthiopa.

stage.l: Enter Arthiopa, her hair dishevelled as before.

sp.l: This living spectacle disturbs and frights
My senses more than all that is dismal about
The dead; no traitor like to that within,
My courage fails me now, which till this hour
I trusted most.
Look on the ruins you
Have made of such a building; Cherubims
Would strive to dwell in it, but that they knew
They must dispossess a soul as good
as they; see how it droops!
The period of
My vexed injurious life draws on apace.
Prepare your valour and your sword, for love
Unto the sacred title which you bear,
You shall not die surprised, without defence,
But try what useful strength is left you, now
Your virtue is gone.
Stay then, I will call to my remembrance all
The noble deeds of my heroic youth,
Whilst growing mighty with thoughts, I may
Behave myself as if I had no guilt.
O hold my Lord! why should you hazard thus
The treasure of your life? impoverishing
the needy remnant of the virtuous world
In my revenge, leave it to the holy powers.
Wilt thou be courteous to her, and desist?
Move but a little back, Arthiopa,
Couldst thou believe me worthy of thy love,
Yet doubt my fortitude to encounter him,
Whose crimes have left him no assistant but
What came from Hell; all that is good forsook
Him when he injured thee. --
It is wearisome to beg your safety now.
By all the fervour of our mutual vows,
I charge thee give me liberty to try
What anger can perform when it is just.
I cannot disobey, though when I see
Your dangers I can die. --
I am resolved for thy assault, yet stay,
That Ladies sufferings hang so heavy on
My soul, that it foretells a longer sleep
Than I would willingly begin; I wish
Thou couldst prepare me with a little wound,
That might let out my lustful blood, and leave
The rest to strengthen me for this dire cause. --
I am good at opening of a vein; there Sir,
Had that afflicted terror in her face
Been hid, thou hadst found more trouble in this victory --
I feele desires of bliss, and those I hope
May prosper, though presented very late.
Depart, forgotten and forgiven. --
Why dost thou shrink? speak Altophil: why dost
Thou bow like tired unwieldy age?
His sword has been too busy here, just here
About the heart. --
The Region of thy love,
I find thou hast a wound by perfect sympathy,
For mine grows sick, and doth desire to bleed.
How fares my Mistress? sweet Arthiopa?
Your pulse must give account of all my health.
Take it not unkindly I shall leave thee now,
My eyes grow dim, and I would furnish them
With everlasting light.
O my dear Lord!
Let me not think that voice was yours.
Alas! that in a loyal Lover death
Must argue some inconstancy, since it is
The first occasion to forsake what we
May never enjoy again.
I shall be forsaken! for I feele
I can delay apace, and keep you company
In this long journey to our last abode. --
First let us seek our vows upon our lips,
They were so strictly kept, that we shall find
Them warm, as if but newly breathed.
These are the funeral rites of love. --
Break heart.
It is the way to show that thou wert true --
Victory! the Fort is taken, victory! --
Your brother died, Gandolpho, in the first
Retreat; you and the soldiers still shall share
My best affection and felicity.
Long live your Highness.
O Sir, the splendour of our triumphs are
Eclipsed, we came too late; behold,
The Tyrant is not only slain, but here
The valiant General lies, his Mistress too,
Embracing, though insensible of love.
Friendship and love are dead; I find
My sorrows are too mighty for my tongue.
The King thus severed from them it appears
He first was killed by Altophil, who straight
Fell after on a lingering hurt, Arthiopa
(This seen) could need no other wound than grief.
The pride and comfort of the war is gone.
A General fit to lead the world against
The force of Hell.
But now we may hang up
Our arms, and yield to every enemy.
Sir, though it is fit you mourn, yet take some care
So to proceed, as that your Subjects may
Be perfectly assured of our victory.
Bear hence these woeful objects of our first
True Elegy; thy statue, Altophil,
Shall in my Palace stand, with sad Arthiopa
Lamenting still; and Amaranta fixed
On the other side, hiding her eyes, that found
Too much of beauty in her Rival's face;
In lasting gold, by old Ephesian Art
Designed, this triple -- Figure I will advance,
Though it will little credit add to Fate,
That made such Lovers so unfortunate.
Our Poet in his fury hath professed,
Yet gravely too, with his hand upon his breast,
That he will never wish to see us thrive,
If by an unhumble Epilogue we strive
To court from you that privilege today
Which you so long have had to damn a Play:
Alas Gentlemen, he knows, to cry Plays down
Is half the business Termers have in town;
And still the reputation of their wit grows strong,
As they can first contemn, be it right or wrong,
Your wives and Country friends may power exact
To find a fault or two in every Act:
But you by his consent most kindly shall
Enjoy the privilege to rail at all:
A happy freedom, which you esteem no less
Than money, health, good wine, or Mistresses;
And he, he hopes, when age declines his wit
From this our stage; to sit and rule in the pit;
Heaven willingly, shall assume a Charter firm,
As yours, to kill a Poet every Term.
And though he never had the confidence,
To tax your judgment in his own defence,
Yet the next night when we your money share,
He will shrewdly guess what your opinions are.
